text: I wish it to be remembered that I was the last man of my tribe to surrender my rifle.
author: Sitting Bull
authorBio: Lakota Sioux chief and holy man (c. 1831 - 1890)

text: I am here by the will of the Great Spirit, and by his will I am chief.
author: Sitting Bull
authorBio: Lakota Sioux chief and holy man (c. 1831 - 1890)

text: Let us put our minds together and see what life we can make for our children.
author: Sitting Bull
authorBio: Lakota Sioux chief and holy man (c. 1831 - 1890)

text: The white man made us many promises, more than I can remember, but they never kept but one; they promised to take our land, and they took it.
author: Sitting Bull
authorBio: Lakota Sioux chief and holy man (c. 1831 - 1890)

text: I will remain what I am until I die, a hunter, and when there are no buffalo or other game I will send my children to hunt and live on prairie.
author: Sitting Bull
authorBio: Lakota Sioux chief and holy man (c. 1831 - 1890)

text: Each man is good in the sight of the Great Spirit.
author: Sitting Bull
authorBio: Lakota Sioux chief and holy man (c. 1831 - 1890)

text: What treaty have the whites ever made with us that they have kept? Not one.
author: Sitting Bull
authorBio: Lakota Sioux chief and holy man (c. 1831 - 1890)

text: If we must die, we die defending our rights.
author: Sitting Bull
authorBio: Lakota Sioux chief and holy man (c. 1831 - 1890)

text: The Great Spirit made us, the Indians, and gave us this land we live in. He gave us the buffalo, the antelope, and the deer for food and clothing.
author: Sitting Bull
authorBio: Lakota Sioux chief and holy man (c. 1831 - 1890)

text: I want to tell you that if the Great Spirit has chosen anyone to be the chief of this country, it is myself.
author: Sitting Bull
authorBio: Lakota Sioux chief and holy man (c. 1831 - 1890)
